Do you think it's impossible to register someone who isn't included in the rental agreement? It seems like an unsolvable task in the case of foreigners.

Children appear after the agreement.

Without being registered in the agreement? Did you have to arrange any utilities?
Yes, the agreement wasn't needed. I only showed my registration. Fortunately, the registration doesn't expire after the end of the ikamet of the person being registered.

Children have never been required in the agreement. Just enough to be a dad or mom.

It's interesting, of course; I went to register, and they required my wife to give her consent, while here my mom was registered without any questions. Don't you have other adult family members? Did they not ask for their consent?
I think it was not consent that was needed, but presence.

PAYMENT ISSUE in Google Play. Information will be useful for Android users who have stopped being able to make purchases in Google Play and have encountered the error 'Make sure the country is correctly set in Google Play.' Solution: 1. Remember that the device must physically be on the network of the local operator (the one indicated as the region in the account and in the payment profile). 2. Check with the bank for any card restrictions. 3. Log into your Google account. 4. Create a support request, describe the problem in short, clear phrases, answer their questions. 5. Wait until they've exhausted their standard useless recipes, then they'll send a link: https://support.google.com/googleplay/contact/fx_block. 6. Go to this link in the same browser where you logged into your account. 7. You will see a window to enter some 'form,' but you don't need to enter anything; it just has a 'submit' button, press it. 8. Wait for 3-5 business days while they check something on their end. 9. Receive a message with the results of the check; they should write that the problem with the transaction has been resolved. 10. Purchases will resume within 24 hours. Thread in 4pda. The issue is specifically with Turkish accounts.

Ankara guide

Kocatepe Mosque
https://maps.app.goo.gl/WtsYtbZZFbAvQ6Nx8?g_st=ic
Very beautiful mosque, and next to it is a great park for walks.

Antikabir
https://maps.app.goo.gl/fZBB1atN3dFZgSkt6?g_st=ic
A must visit. Atat√ºrk is buried there, there's a museum below, plus his cars. I recommend timing a visit to the changing of the guard, it seems every hour, but I'm not sure. It's a very bright performance; we enjoyed it a lot, even despite the extreme heat then)
And don't forget sunglasses, as the square's floor is made of light marble and the bright sun can be very blinding, and a guy almost fainted from it. And water.

Hamam√∂n√º
https://maps.app.goo.gl/if8p2CnubUDyLX1M7?g_st=ic
A historic area with authentic buildings, streets of bars, and various workshops. A very beautiful and pleasant place.

The Fortress
https://maps.app.goo.gl/kPHbWtEV2eKZeJgeA?g_st=ic
An incredible view of the city in 360 degrees.

Museum of Anatolian Civilizations
https://maps.app.goo.gl/VkbMt2j8X1T6YoGf6?g_st=ic
We're not history lovers, but it's quite decent overall. We mostly wanted a place to hide from the heat, so we went there.

Rahmi M. Koc Museum Ankara

‚ùìCan a resident transfer currency from their declared account in a friendly country to the account of a close relative in a bank of the same country?

Yes, they can.

Russian currency regulation establishes a general rule: currency operations between residents are prohibited.

Residents are all citizens of the Russian Federation and foreigners who have a Russian residence permit. In this context, we do not use the term "tax resident of the Russian Federation", it is similar but different.

There are exceptions to the general prohibition:

‚Äî If the transfer of money takes place between residents who live most of the calendar year outside of Russia, it is a legal currency operation.

For example, in 2023, resident A transfers money from their foreign account to resident B's foreign account. If both resident A and resident B spent more than 183 days abroad during the period from January 1 to December 31, 2023, then such a transfer is recognized as a permitted currency operation.

‚Äî If the transfer of money occurs between residents who are spouses or close relatives, it is also a legal currency operation.

Close relatives are parents and children; grandparents, grandchildren; brothers and sisters. In this case, it does not matter how many days such residents live in Russia or abroad.

For example, in 2023, resident A transfers money from their foreign account to resident B's foreign account. If resident A and resident B are spouses, then such a transfer is recognized as a permitted currency operation.

The fact that the account is declared does not matter. Even if the Russian tax service is unaware of the account, such a currency operation would be legal.

The fact that the account is opened in a bank of a friendly country also does not matter. Russian currency legislation regarding transfers of money between foreign accounts does not distinguish rules depending on whether the account is opened in a friendly country or not.

Currency operations between residents are prohibited by general rule, but there are exceptions.

2) Transfers from the foreign account of a resident to the foreign account of another resident are also allowed if both residents live outside of Russia for most of the calendar year.

3) There is another rare case where transfers from the foreign account of a resident to the foreign account of another resident are allowed if both residents have been recognized as non-tax residents of the Russian Federation due to foreign sanctions.

1. Not a word is written about the 99 card at the cash registers of any museum (and we have already visited about 5 in Cappadocia)

5. After that, entrance to museums is only through a code generated in the app. Each from their own app. Otherwise, the parent will have to log in each time to generate a code for the child. Thus, the mystery of the title 'Digital' is revealed.

We decided to terminate the contract with T√ºrktelekom for home internet. There were a few months left until the end of the contract. We went to several places to return the rented modem. Some refused completely, the others asked from 2000 to 4000 lira for early termination. It seemed strange to us to pay more for contract termination than to pay the bills for the remaining months.

But then we learned a lifehack. It turns out that in Turkey you can terminate a contract with any telecommunication company completely free of charge. To do this, you need to submit a request for e-devlet to terminate the contract. Which we did. Then we took a screenshot from e-devlet with the request number and went to the office of the company‚Äôs directorate (T√ºrk Telekom M√ºd√ºrl√ºƒü√º, definitely to the directorate since small offices are ordinary private ones who "earn" as they can), showed them the request, they took the modem, filled out the termination form and only asked us to pay one bill for one month. And that's it.
I hope this information will be useful to someone.

Link to the application form: https://www.turkiye.gov.tr/btk-abonelik-fesih-basvurusu
The only thing needed for this application is additional verification. The simplest is if you have an account in a Turkish bank, you can authorize through it.

Recently I met a familiar Turk, and he told me a story that happened to him which made me think again and raise the topic of p2p trading in Turkish lira. The most common type of fraud that has come to Turkey is the cancellation of bank payments. Russia has long moved away from this, but the Turkish banking system suffers. Especially the makers suffer from it. I've written a lot about this, saying, drilling that being a maker in Turkish lira is dangerous. Scammers send you lira, you release Tether and then they immediately cancel the payment. Your amount gets blocked by the bank until circumstances are clarified. You go to the bank, and they just shrug and say that only the one who claimed it can remove the block. Then you find the sender, and he demands from you, "Send me 50%, and then I'll unlock it," and then you can only unlock it through court, paying lawyers and spending up to a year of your life. This mainly happens on Binance Global, as Binance TR does not have a p2p section. The moral: I highly recommend not trading with the reception of lira on your cards via p2p. My acquaintance traded both as a taker and a maker. Turkey is a country with a population that is not the most educated and life-experienced. Scammers take advantage of this. More and more fraudulent schemes from Russia and Ukraine are starting to come to Turkey. More and more I‚Äôm getting private messages about requests for processing black traffic. And if cheap and free iPhones are already becoming a thing of the past, the banners "We'll help you close your loan for 10% of the debt" are gaining traction. The scheme is simple, like my life: a not-so-bright Turk saw such a banner on a dating site. He clicked. There‚Äôs a solution in about 10 minutes. They give a card (of my acquaintance), a victim sends lira, my acquaintance delivers Tether. Everyone seems to be happy. But the victim doesn‚Äôt get the desired. And in the best case, the victim forgets, and in the worst, goes to the police. And it seems like the situation with my acquaintance - he's a victim too, but in the Turkish legal system, things aren't that simple. And the price of the issue is only 6,000 lira. My acquaintance shows 100 pages of statements from banks where deals are done for 1 million lira, which if he were a scammer, he wouldn‚Äôt do for 6,000 lira. Luckily, he's a Turk who knows the language; I would have been immediately sent to prison for a long time. The worst thing is that in Turkish law, there's no opportunity for reconciliation. He says "Let's compensate the victim?" You can compensate, but the case won't be closed. The case will definitely go to court. And it turned out that he had four such cases against him!!!!! They put bracelets on him and took him to check for drugs in the hospital. That‚Äôs how it‚Äôs done. In the hospital, he also met someone detained on suspicion of murder, but for some reason, he was without handcuffs. My acquaintance asked, "Why am I in handcuffs for 6,000 lira, and the murderer isn‚Äôt? The hospital formality looked like this: Doctor "Are you healthy? Do you feel normal? Yes? Sign here. No drugs detected. Then they took him to the temporary detention facility to wait for a judge. The incident happened on Friday. The judge only came on Saturday. He looked tired and it was clear they had been celebrating well. Maybe that saved him. Or maybe it was the fact that he has small kids, has citizenship, but the escort said, "You are the first one released; the judge is taking a risk." In short, they imposed a travel ban on him; he must report to the police every day and is prohibited from leaving the country. They could have marinated him in pre-trial detention for a year. Nobody knows when the trial will be. He has already given far more money to the lawyer than 6,000. Whether he will be imprisoned in the end or get a conditional release, it‚Äôs also unknown. But it certainly saved him that he is a citizen of Turkey. If he were a foreigner, he would have flown into prison for an indefinite period. That's how he traded. By the way, the investigator said, "If it were Binance TR, everything would have been resolved quickly. But Binance Global doesn‚Äôt respond to our requests." But there is no p2p trading on Binance TR, and thus there wouldn't have been any problems. That's how they protect both themselves and clients. By the way, many respectable exchanges like OKEX also do not have p2p sections. The conclusion: I highly recommend not getting involved in Turkish trading on exchanges for lira on p2p. It is at a peak of fraud right now. It‚Äôs so dangerous that you can‚Äôt even imagine.
When he realized there were more of us and the windows were open, he decided that it was easier for him to bail than to sue usüòÖ.

Ziraat Bank no longer opens accounts in rubles: Russian businessmen are facing problems üí∏

The Turkish state bank Ziraat has stopped opening accounts in rubles, which has caused dissatisfaction among Russian citizens doing business in Turkey. At the branch of the bank in Ankara, this information was confirmed, with no explanation given for such a decision.

Previously, opening ruble accounts was possible for clients with residency permits or work rights in Turkey. Now, however, holders of such accounts face increased scrutiny and the need to convert rubles into Turkish lira to carry out transactions.

Meanwhile, in private banks such as Denizbank, ruble accounts are opened on the condition of a deposit, although issues with bank transfers between Russia and Turkey are still relevant.

Bloomberg: Turkey has applied to join BRICS

Turkey officially applied to join BRICS a few months ago as the country seeks to strengthen its global influence and establish new connections beyond its traditional Western allies, Bloomberg reports, citing sources familiar with the matter. 

According to the sources, the decision to join BRICS is a result of the lack of progress in Turkey's long-standing attempts to join the European Union. Turkey and the EU have been negotiating on this issue since 2005. Another reason for this decision may be disagreements with other NATO members amid Turkey's close ties with Russia. 

Further expansion of BRICS may be discussed during the summit in Kazan, which will take place from October 22 to 24, the agency's sources said. Agency representatives note that in the opinion of the Turkish president's administration, Recep Tayyip Erdoƒüan, the "geopolitical center of gravity" is shifting from developed economies.

üì∞Rental scandals are not dying down: new requirements shock tenants

Conflicts between landlords and tenants continue to occupy public attention. In one of the recent cases, the tenant paid 20,000 lira for rent, but the landlord stated that the market price is 40,000 lira and requested 35,000 lira. The parties could not reach an agreement, and the situation was resolved through mediation. 
According to Dr. Umut Metin, a representative of the Association of Mediators (TURAMEP), during the negotiations, the tenant acknowledged the fairness of the market price stated but could not afford to pay 35,000 lira. As a result, it was agreed that the tenant would continue to pay 20,000 lira as before but would agree to vacate the premises in 6 months. This is one of the common examples of solutions reached through mediation.

Other examples:
In the second case, the tenant refused to pay rent of 12,000 lira and filed a complaint against the landlord with the prosecution, accusing him of threats and insults. However, during the negotiations, the tenant agreed to withdraw the complaint by signing an eviction agreement and continued to live in the apartment at the same rate.
The third case involved a conflict between neighbors due to noise. The parties came to an agreement during the mediation meeting, and the neighbor promised to install soundproofing to eliminate the problem.

By the way, cat lovers - I was very disappointed after a while of using silica gel. It doesn't lock in the smell at all.

There is less dust from it than from bentonite, but there is more urea odor. Bentonite clumps, and you throw away all the waste. But silica gel absorbs urea and doesn‚Äôt hold the smell at all. The package says it's for one cat for a month, but in fact, it's a lie. I poured in 2 packages for one cat - after a week it was already a disaster. And it costs a lot.

We also use soy here, but the choice is sad.

Wooden litter is the most disgusting thing I‚Äôve ever used. Stench and sawdust all over the house. The point of soy litter is that it clumps well, holds odors decently, but you can flush it down the toilet; it turns into mush in water.

Before it was only Japanese type, but some time ago apparently the Chinese mastered it and it started to be sold in Russia under many local brands. It looks like it‚Äôs packaged from one bag. The Japanese type was significantly different when it was still available.

It's not the smell of sawdust, but of urine in it. Plus, it spreads tiny wet sawdust all over the apartment. But I had big cats that did their business on an industrial scale, maybe for smaller breeds the problem is less.

No, I have a small cat 3.5kg, a closed litter box, a mat, a separate room for his litter box, but the bentonite is everywhere on two floors, I‚Äôm afraid that if he drags it on his paws, he may eat part of it. In Turkey, a new draft decree is being prepared, according to which landlords and tenants will be prohibited from making rental payments in cash. The Ministry of Finance and the Tax Administration are developing measures for mandatory rental payments through banks or postal offices (PTT). According to the project, landlords and tenants who make cash payments will be fined. The minimum fine will be 5000 lira, even if 10% of the rent amount is less than this threshold. Fines will be imposed separately on both parties for each transaction. For large entrepreneurs and representatives of free professions, the fine can reach 20,000 lira. It is expected that this draft decree will be implemented to tighten control over rental payments and prevent tax evasion. Earlier today, there was talk about introducing a penalty for making cash payments exceeding 7000 lira. Currently, the law has not yet been adopted and is in the development stage.
